Articles.Content:
So before 0.90 comes out and everyone builds space shuttles, I thought I'd jump the gun.

This is a Mk-1 sized space shuttle for taking a single Kerbal up to LKO. I has docking capability and about 500m/s dV using its OMS engines.

Its not actually finished yet. Fuel is a bit too short so it uses its own dV to achieve orbit. Also the balance isn't quite right so the ascent is... interesting. I'll upload the craft file once these details are sorted.

Craft File: https://www.dropbox.com/s/mxqtngs1z976fl0/Mk-1%20Shuttle.craft?dl=0

Launch at 75% throttle to allow the SAS chance to adjust. Then you can throttle up.

It uses a conventional shuttle layout without engines on the fuel tank.

Boosters separated

Orbit Achieved!

The glide ratio is positively terrifying. The flare on landing is essential to reduce vertical speed.

Back at base. I overshot and had to use the Island.

Edited December 12, 2014 by Frozen_Heart

Couldn't comment before, but now that I have the time I have to say: that is cute indeed. And one suggestion: I think if you had the ET drain from the bottom up (so it's CoM moves forwards as it empties) you would have a smaller change of CoM/CoT during flight. It's only a hunch eyeballing things, but I have the impression you should have pitch authority pretty much maxed out after you drop the SRBs. Only a visual estimate, mind you, I could be very wrong, but going by my record lately balancing weird stuff... In any case, if you still have control problems, just add a crapton of fuel more and a couple of vernors on top: you will be amazed at the control authority you gain suddenly. That's the brute force way.

Oh, and add a probe core so you can use it as a rescue ship! That way you can legitimately use this on career.

Ok I've overcome my laziness and put up the craft file.

A few small changes have been made at Rune's suggestion.

These include:

More Fuel in the external tank. The OMS is no longer needed to achieve a 75km orbit. I usually drop it just before to avoid debris.

A probe core for rescue missions. The shuttle can be sent up unmanned to rescue those pesky kerbals.

Fuel flow changes to make control a lot easier.
Hm.. I see you have followed Scott Manley's advice from his videos closely. Well done.
